newsitem.title: MEXICO: Moderate tremors rock Mexico, Nicaragua.
newsitem.headline: Moderate tremors rock Mexico, Nicaragua.

text.p: An earthquake measuring 5.1 on the Richter scale hit western Mexico on Thursday about two hours after a 5.7-sized quake shook Nicaragua, but there were no reports of damage or injuries in either country.
The Mexico quake, just after 11 a.m. local time (noon EDT) (1600 GMT), hit just offshore from the resort city of Acapulco, 185 miles (300 km) southwest of Mexico City.
"We consider the earthquake a mild tremor and we have no reports of damage," said a spokesman at the earthquake centre in Mexico's National Autonomous University.
A Red Cross spokesman in Acapulco told Reuters there were no reports of damage or injuries in that coastal city.
The Nicaragua quake took place at 8:01 local time (10:01 a.m. EDT) (1401 GMT) and was centred in the Pacific Ocean some 96 miles (155 km) east of Managua.
U.S. President Bill Clinton had been on a state visit to Mexico until Wednesday night, but was in Costa Rica on Thursday, which neighbours Nicaragua.
During this century, two large earthquakes in 1931 and 1972 nearly destroyed Managua.

On Sept. 19-20, 1985, twin earthquakes devastated Mexico City and nearby states. They measured 8.1 and 7.3 on the Richter scale. The death toll was more than 8,000, and damage was estimated at $5 billion.
